channel.title: ASF JIRA
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [HBASE-12485] Maintain SeqId monotonically increasing
item.description:
We added FLUSH, REGION CLOSE events into WAL, for each those events the region SeqId is bumped.

The issue comes from region close operation. Because when opening a region, we use flushed SeqId from store files while after store flush during region close we still write COMMIT_FLUSH, REGION_CLOSE events etc which respectively bump up SeqId. Therefore, the region opening SeqId is lower than it should be.

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.

comments.comment: Good one Jeffrey Zhong (you know sequenceid is my favorite subject!)
Submit Patch for QA run. The patch basically uses SeqId file to store region latest seqId during region close & open. Thanks.
Resubmit for QA run

Throw exception rather than WARN.
3547 LOG.warn("Found decreasing SeqId. PreId=" + currentEditSeqId + " key=" + key
3548 + "; edit=" + val);
It will never happen, right? (smile)

I did not realize we were writing a file into region with the sequenceid. Better than into zk I'd say. Should the special file instead be named with a dot prefix like other special files (see head of HRegionFileSystem for list – .regioninfo, .tmp, etc.)

Thanks Stack for the review!

Throw exception rather than WARN.

This is a good point. If we do this then the region won't be opened anymore unless human intention(it might be also hard as it needs get rid of certain edits from recovered edits files).

dot prefix like other special files

I tried this before but hbck gives some errors. Let me try it again to see if I can make hbck happy.

On first point, ok. Log as ERROR then?

On second, yeah, would be good if all 'special' files were in one place (hbck is going to run into these sequence files one day – smile)

This message is automatically generated.

Stack if we use ".sqeid' then hbck reports "ERROR: Found lingering reference file" error. It's due to we have a bug in the code: FSUtils#getTableStoreFilePathMap() where we didn't skip "recovered.edits" that is on same folder level as column family. I fixed the issue in the attached patch as following. 


--- hbase-server/src/main/java/org/apache/hadoop/hbase/util/FSUtils.java

+++ hbase-server/src/main/java/org/apache/hadoop/hbase/util/FSUtils.java

@@ -1508,6 +1508,9 @@ public abstract class FSUtils {

       FileStatus[] familyDirs = fs.listStatus(dd, familyFilter);

       for (FileStatus familyDir : familyDirs) {

         Path family = familyDir.getPath();

+        if (family.getName().equals(HConstants.RECOVERED_EDITS_DIR)) {

+          continue;

+        }

         // now in family, iterate over the StoreFiles and

While if we use ".sqeid", the old hbck won't work. This will cause issue for rollback and during upgrade if a user uses old hbck. Should we still keep "_seqid"? what do you suggest? Thanks.

Nice find on bug in code over recovered.edits.

This will cause issue for rollback and during upgrade if a user uses old hbck.

Rollback is not supported.

Is hbck supposed to work during a rolling upgrade? Would it be too much to expect that an operator use the newer version of hbck during an upgrade?

Do you mean to write '.sqeid' or do you intend to write '.seqid'?

Just trying to minimize the different ways in which we designate 'special files'
The v2 patch addressed Stack comments by using ".seqid" as seqid file name suffix.

Rolling upgrades will always require use of the newest Hbck. Otherwise new features could cause hbck to double assign regions because it doesn't know about some new thing ( any changes to .meta. )

I like what Elliott said.

Jeffrey Zhong Thanks for making the change (and for doing old and new style handling). +1

We only parse with the new style file name ending in below....

698 Long tmpSeqId = Long.parseLong(fileName.substring(0, fileName.length()
688 - SEQUENCE_ID_FILE_SUFFIX.length())); 699 - SEQUENCE_ID_FILE_SUFFIX_LENGTH));

That is because if old style, its stale... not pertinent to this recovery?

Previous, we just added 1 always when we did this:

long nextSeqid = maxSeqId;

But you don't do it when you add the safety margin any more because "why add 1 when we just added 100000?" – that is the reasoning?

Next time

688 if (isSequenceIdFile(p))

{ 689 return true; 690 }

691 return false;

should be just 'return isSequenceIdFile(p);'

Nice patch and fix Jeffrey Zhong – +1
